node.text:
Bone carving is an ancient art form popularized by royals in India around the 16th century. More recently, a shrinking market and scarcity of materials have pushed many carvers away from the craft. Jalaluddin Akhtar and his son Akheel are determined to keep the craft alive in Lucknow.

#BoneCarving #India #Handmade #FamilyRun #Lucknow #IndianCraft

node.title: How bone carvers in India are keeping a prehistoric art alive

node.text:
YouTube is filled with viral videos of Jeeps scaling vertical rock walls. While most of these vehicles are modified, there's a reason Jeeps are so often the choice of these extreme off-roaders, or rock crawlers. From their unmatched standard features to the number of ways they can be modified, Jeeps are the perfect tool for crawling.

Editor's Note: In this video we refer to rock walls as "vertical walls", this is misstated. While the rock walls shown in the video are steep, they are not at a 90 degree angle. Also, at 4:21 we showed a cyclist hill-climbing easier by shifting upward on their rear gear cluster. A cyclist climbing hills would ideally shift downward on the rear gear cluster, and lower on the bicycle's chainrings. Insider regrets the error.

#jeeps #JeepClimb #Transportation #RockCrawler #RockCrawling

node.text:
Starting a weed business isn't easy. It can take $1 million in startup capital to even get a license. And to keep a cannabis business going? That means jumping through complicated regulation hoops. If they can play the game right, cannabis entrepreneurs could be set up for success in an exploding marijuana industry. But with weed still federally illegal, companies could face fines or jail time if they don't follow the rules. We visited three companies in Colorado and Oregon to see how they're dealing with the ever-changing regulations. Could things get easier if weed becomes federally legal?

Featuring @magichourcannabis.

#Marijuana #THC #Cannabis #Business #WeedBusiness

node.title: Why starting a marijuana business is so hard | Big Business

node.text:
One of the biggest cargo planes in the world, the C-17 Globemaster III has a payload capacity of 172,000 pounds. The massive plane is used in a variety of missions, including evacuation efforts and troop transport in Afghanistan after the Taliban took control of Kabul in August 2021. This aircraft requires only three crew members to fly: a pilot, a copilot, and a loadmaster. Insider spent three days at Travis Air Force Base, where we observed the training required to fly these giant $340 million feats of engineering. That training included mastering the flight simulator, planning the proper execution of a mission, and then putting that mission into action with an instructor pilot and performing it in the sky.

#bootcamp #airforce #planes #military #pilot

node.title: What it takes to fly the $340 million C-17 Globemaster III | Boot Camp

node.text: Sam Bernstein and April Koh press pause on their busy days as entrepreneurs to reflect on the companies they each founded at a young age. For Bernstein, that was Table22, which helps restaurants create new revenue streams through subscription kits. For Koh, that was Spring Health, which connects employers to mental wellness resources for workers. Their conversation over coffee, thanks to Philips Espresso 3200 LatteGo, reveals a new style of leadership that prioritizes openness and vulnerability and underscores the need to step away and recharge.

node.title: Two young entrepreneurs reflect on the strength that comes from self-care

node.text:
Polaroid was a photographic giant, at one point controlling two-thirds of the instant camera market in the US. As the digital revolution took over, Polaroid was left exposed, and forced to shut down production in 2008. But the company has found new life thanks to the Impossible Project, by bringing Polaroid’s technology into the digital world.

#Polaroid #Photography #Fujifilm #Kodak #Cameras #Photographer

node.title: The rise and fall of Polaroid | Rise And Fall

node.text:
Durian’s smell is famously divisive. But in Asia and the Pacific Islands, durian is known as the “King of Fruit.” Nonthaburi, Thailand, is known for cultivating some of the most sought-after durian varieties: Kan Yao and Mon Thong. In 2019, one Nonthaburi, or Nont, durian sold at auction for $48,000. So, what makes this pungent, spiky fruit so expensive?

#durian #soexpensive #fruit #nonthaburi #thailand #expensive

node.title: Why Nonthaburi durians are so expensive | So Expensive

node.text:
A lavender farm in West Virginia is restoring land destroyed by coal mining and providing jobs in a state struggling as the fossil fuel energy is on its way out. There are over 6 million acres of abandoned coal mines across the US, and more could go to waste if coal companies don’t restore their land.

#WestVirginia #Lavender #CoalMining #RestoringLand #FossilFuel #Coal #Farming #Environment

node.title: Can lavender save land ruined by coal mining? | World Wide Waste

node.text:
From finishing each piece with a glossy shine to cutting down blocks of wood by hand — it takes over 200 artisans to craft just one Steinway grand piano. Steinway is one of the most famous piano brands in the world, and depending on the model, it can be one of the priciest. A Steinway Model D ebony concert piano will cost you $187,000. Famous pianists and music icons like Billy Joel and Lang Lang play on Steinway pianos. But with several other high-end piano brands on the market, why are musicians so drawn to Steinway? And why are these pianos so expensive?

#Steinway #SteinwayandSons #Piano #Music #MusicalInstrument #SteinwayPiano #Musicians

node.title: Why Steinway grand pianos are so expensive | So Expensive

node.text:
Pottery is a traditional industry in Gaza, supported by families like Sabri Atallah's. But decades of armed conflict and political strife have put these artisans' livelihoods at risk. We visited Sabri Atallah & Sons Pottery Factory before, during, and after the May 2021 attacks to see how he is keeping the craft alive.

Sabri only sells his pottery locally and does not have a website.

#Gaza #Israel #Palestine #Pottery #PotteryShop #MakingPottery #Familyrun #PotteryFactory

node.title: How This Pottery Shop Survived Six Decades Of War And Conflict In Gaza

node.text:
Powerful greenhouse gases lurk inside most refrigerators. One recycling company in Guatemala City is working to keep them out of the atmosphere. Its work is partially funded by carbon offset credits, which experts say can help fight the climate crisis but require close scrutiny.

#Guatemala #GreenhouseGases #ClimateChange #ClimateCrisis #recycle #RecycleFridge #Environment

node.title: Why refrigerators are so hard to recycle | World Wide Waste

node.accessibility_caption: Photo of billionaire investor Larry Silverstein with the headline, "The billionaire who is still rebuilding the World Trade Center might not live to see it finished"

node.text:
Twenty years after 9/11, Larry Silverstein has two more towers to get off the ground. The 90-year-old thinks he can do it — even as offices sit empty.

Click the link in our bio to subscribe to Insider and read more about the billionaire who is still rebuilding the World Trade Center, even though he might not live to see it finished.

Story by Daniel Geiger.

(Credit: @themusingeye/@insiderimage, Silverstein Properties)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo of billionaire investor Larry Silverstein with the headline, "The billionaire who is still rebuilding the World Trade Center might not live to see it finished"

Photo of Silverstein holding giant scissors after cutting the ribbon at the opening of 7 World Trade Center in May 2006 with the text, "It was early 2020, and major corporations were enamored with the World Trade Center. Larry Silverstein, the now-90-year-old billionaire developer, has built three towers and is planning two more at the Lower Manhattan site."

Graphic of architect Daniel Libeskind's original vision for the World Trade Center site with the quote, "In another three or four weeks, we would have had 100% of the tower filled," Silverstein said in a recent conversation with Insider from his conference-room-sized corner office on the 38th floor of 7 World Trade Center. "Then the damnedest thing happened. The pandemic hit, and those deals vanished."

Photo of Silverstein looking out at construction through the window of a completed 7 World Trade Center in 2006 with the text, "As with much of the rest of the office market across the city and the country, few corporate tenants have been willing to take major blocks of space at the World Trade Center since the arrival of COVID-19. More broadly, ominous signs about future demand have arisen from a corporate world that has been increasingly willing to embrace remote work."

Photo of Silverstein at his desk in 7 World Trade Center in August 2021 with the text, "Silverstein has long said he wants to complete 2 World Trade Center — the final commercial skyscraper at the site — in his lifetime, and he remains unbowed even after entering his 10th decade in May."
A graphic shows a woman wearing an orange sweater speaking to a man wearing a black sweater. It reads: Why experts say you shouldn't wear orange to an interview

node.text:
Recruiters use job interviews to see whether a candidate is the right fit for a company. Your teamwork skills, the way you speak, and the clothes you wear will be closely assessed. 

Recruiters recommend neutral tones — but orange can be associated with unprofessionalism. 

Click the link in our bio to read the full story by Cristina Fernández Esteban and Qayyah Moynihan.

(Credit: Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: A graphic shows a woman wearing an orange sweater speaking to a man wearing a black sweater. It reads: Why experts say you shouldn't wear orange to an interview

A graphic reads: Clothing speaks

Choosing what to wear is, perhaps, almost as important as preparing your answers and questions.

Clothes say a lot about the person wearing them — they're loaded with connotations. 

For example, expensive shoes and sneakers have long been used by the most powerful millennials as a status symbol.

A graphic reads: Stick with neutrals 

Orange was the least recommended color to wear to an interview by human resources professionals according to a study from job portal Career Builder. 

The reasons for this were that the likelihood of being associated with a lack of professionalism while wearing orange was greater. 

The most recommended colors were neutrals: blue, black and gray.

A graphic reads: What you should wear

The best option is to try to adapt the style of the company interviewing you. 

You can check the company's social media profiles to find out if they have a particular dress code. 

If you find their dress code is pretty casual, CareerBuilder suggests going for something a little more formal during the interview regardless.
Graphic of Elizabeth Holmes and Sunny Balwani with the headline, "The Elizabeth Holmes trial: The defense wins the opening round"

node.text:
USA v. Elizabeth A. Holmes began Wednesday morning in a federal courthouse in San Jose, California. The trial is taking place because of Theranos, Holmes' blood-testing company that left its investors in the lurch. She is standing trial over claims of criminal fraud.

Insider's Adam Lashinsky was at the trial for its first week. Lawyers for the Theranos founder told a more compelling story during opening arguments than the prosecution.

Click the link in our bio to read the full story from what each side had to say to three mysterious lookalikes, and a reluctant teen juror.

Story by Adam Lashinsky.

(Credit: @tyliedesigns/Insider, Getty Images, Reuters, Theranos, Walgreens, Safeway)
#elizabethholmes #elizabethholmestrial #theranos #sunnybalwani #usavselizabethholmes

node.accessibility_caption: Graphic of Elizabeth Holmes and Sunny Balwani with the headline, "The Elizabeth Holmes trial: The defense wins the opening round"

Text graphic with a cutout of Elizabeth Holmes and the text, "Day 1: USA v. Elizabeth A. Holmes began Wednesday morning in a federal courthouse in San Jose, California, the closest thing Silicon Valley has to a capital. There was a circus-like atmosphere to the 
first day — everyone, it
seemed, wanted to see the
former wunderkind boss of
Theranos, the blood-testing
company that left its
investors in the lurch,
stand trial over claims
of criminal fraud."

Text graphic with the text, "Opening arguments: The prosecution, as expected, portrayed Holmes as a bald-faced liar who deceived partners, investors, and patients alike, thereby committing fraud.But the defense, to my surprise, opted for a shockingly simple assertion, given how thoroughly the Theranos scandal has been documented over the past six years. Holmes, the defense argued, bamboozled no one. She never made a dime on Theranos and was guilty of nothing more than naivete and making bad business decisions."

Text graphic with a cutout of a Theranos machine with the text, "Prosecution's arguments: The prosecution's argument seems strongest with regard to investors. Robert Leach, an assistant US attorney, said Theranos "raised hundreds of millions of dollars based on false and misleading representations, some made orally with investors, some with PowerPoints, some in news articles."If prosecutors can show that
Holmes lied to investors
and brought in money in
the process, they'll have
their "conspiracy to
defraud" case
buttoned up. "

Text graphic with a cutout of Elizabeth Holmes and the text, "Defense's arguments: "The government would have you believe her entire life is a fraud. That is not true," said defense attorney Lance Wade. "Elizabeth Holmes worked herself to the bone for 15 years trying to make lab testing cheaper and more accessible. She poured her heart and her soul into that effort. Now, in the end, Theranos failed, and Miss
Holmes walked away with nothing.
But failure is not a crime. Trying
your hardest and coming up short
is not a crime. The villain the
government just described is a
living, breathing human being
who did her best every
day and is innocent.""

Text graphic with a cutout of Sunny Balwani and the text, "Sunny Balwani: So if Holmes is innocent, who's the guilty party? Wade offered many candidates for what went wrong at Theranos including a list of people and companies he threw under the bus. First there was Ramesh
"Sunny" Balwani, poor
Miss Elizabeth's
Svengali-like lover and
business partner,
who oversaw
lab operations."

Text graphic with the text, "Walgreens and Safeway: Then there were Walgreens and Safeway, which the prosecution will argue were the victims of fraud. But to the defense, the two companies knew what they were getting into, Wade argued, because they had turned Theranos "upside down" to assess the risks. "In corporate America it's called due diligence," he said, "and they did a lot of it. They identified many risks, but they wanted a deal.""

Text graphic with the text, "Final thoughts:Wade dissed sophisticated
investors, portraying them not as
victims of Holmes' lies but as greedy profiteers who bungled their
own risk assessments.But will this line of argument work? To spring Holmes, Wade need only plant a seed of doubt in a single juror. The story the defense told was highly entertaining and that, as much or more than the law, is often what counts with a jury."

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on September 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'INSIDER How OSHA, the agency tasked with enforcing Biden's vaccine mandate, works And how it'll go about making companies with more than 100 employees require vaccines.'.

node.text:
The Occupational Safety and Health Administration, commonly known as OSHA, has been tasked with implementing and enforcing the new vaccine mandate that President Joe Biden announced Thursday. 

Under the mandate, all businesses with more than 100 employees will have to require COVID-19 vaccinations or submit employees to weekly testing.

The White House said OSHA is drafting the rule, which will affect more than 80 million workers, and will enforce it once it goes into place. The administration did not say under what deadline OSHA will be drafting the rule or when it will go into effect.

Click the link in our bio for more details.

Story by Kelsey Vlamis.

(Credit: Cristina Quicler/ Contributor/ Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on September 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'INSIDER How OSHA, the agency tasked with enforcing Biden's vaccine mandate, works And how it'll go about making companies with more than 100 employees require vaccines.'.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on September 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER What is OSHA? The mission of OSHA, which is housed in the Department of Labor, is to 'ensure safe and healthful working conditions for workers." The Occupational Safety and Health Act created OSHA and gave itjurisdiction over most private sector employers in the US and their workers across all 50 states, as well as federal government workers. All employers covered by OSHA are required to comply with the agency's health and safety standards.'.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on September 10, 2021. May be an image of ‎text that says '‎INSIDER How will OSHA enforce the vaccine mandate? In the COVID-1 action plan announced by the White House on Thursday, Biden specifically directed OSHA to issue an emergency temporary standard (ETS) for the private sector vaccine mandate. Per the agency, if OSHA determines that "workers are in grave danger due to exposure to toxic ۔c or agents determined to be toxic or physically harmful or to new hazards," it can bypass the standard procedure and implement an ETS.‎'‎.

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on September 10, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER What difficulties will OSHA face in enforcing the vaccine mandate? Republican lawmakers like Texas Gov. Greg Abbott and Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp have already vowed to fight the vaccine mandate, so it's likely the ETS will be challenged in court. If challenged, the ETS will remain in effect unless a court specifically blocks it. The courts will likely have to determine whether the Commerce Clause of the Constitution gives OSHA the authority to broadly mandate vaccines, Brian Dean Abramson, a vaccine law expert, told Insider.'.

node.text:
Biden is requiring employers with more than 100 employees to mandate vaccines or weekly testing. Federal employees and healthcare workers are also required to be vaccinated, per Biden's new plan.

The new measures hope to counteract Delta's threat in the US. Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on September 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing, outdoors and text.

node.text:
This week, El Salvador became the first country to accept Bitcoin as legal tender. The rollout – just three months after it was first proposed – was far from smooth, and many people here remain skeptical. 

The radical experiment in cryptocurrency was designed to dynamize the economy, and make it cheaper for 3 million Salvadorans living abroad to send remittances back home. 

But in stores and at markets around the capital, San Salvador, the rollout was plagued with glitches. Those who tried to use Bitcoin, mostly to get the $30 dollar incentive from the government, found that the infrastructure that had cost millions in public spending was not functioning.

Read the full story at the link in our bio.

(Credit: Camilo Freedman)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on September 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing, outdoors and text.

Photo by Business Insider on September 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and text that says 'INSIDER LACLAS DECHAZ The rollout was plagued with glitches The new Bitcoin ATMs, which were meant to convert the cryptocurrency into cash, weren't working, and there were widespread problems downloading the Chivo crypto wallets. DICTAD In the capital, 1,000 people took to the streets to protest, holding signs demanding that the government focus on El Salvador's real issues.'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'INSIDER "People are rejecting the implementation of Bitcoin because it hasn't been done in a way that would benefit the working class." Xenia Barrera One O of the protestors'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'INSIDER OKYO 7 of every 10 Salvadorans oppose the Bitcoin law In El Salvador, where less than half of the population has Internet access, the announcement was met with less fanfare. On an even more basic level, in a country where around 70% of the population doesn' have a bank account, the fact that Bitcoin is not tangible it's not money you can hold it in your hand- scares people.'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'INSIDER "El Salvador already has had to get a $200 million dollar loan for Bitcoin to go into circulation. The same amount of money that could power a public hospital for a year." Tatiana Marroquin A Salvadoran economist'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'INSIDER strike The ghost of a itco Accepted currency change past One reason behind the widespread distrust of Bitcoin Acce is that El Salvador has been through something like this before, and it ended badly. In 2001, the U.S. dollar was made a egal tender, even as the Salvadoran Colon remained in circulation Then, the Colon was pulled out of circulation, and prices for basic necessities soared.'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 09, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'INSIDER For the country's wealthy minority, things are different When the currency went live on Tuesday, there were parties at upscale clubs around the capital. One party, in the city's financial district, was packed with tourists who had traveled from everywhere between Miami to Oslo to reach El Salvador to watch as the Bitcoin law went into effect.'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER "This is the future. We're just excited to see what's going to happen, get a grasp on what's going to be reality for us." Raul One O of the partygoers'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 09, 2021. May be an image of text that says '#bitcot aceptan aceptan INSIDER LM The Bitcoin Beach In the beach town of El Zonte, about 60 miles from the Salvadoran capital, Bitcoin has been around for a while. Here, surfers, tourists, and locals pay for their snow cones, pupusas, and even some basic services such as electricity, using Bitcoin. Known as the "Bitcoin Beach Project,' the first Bitcoin teller machine was installed here after an anonymous donor donated in cryptocurrency.'.
Aerial photo of a cargo ship stuck in the Suez Canal with the healine, "Another massive cargo ship was stuck in the Suez Canal, but this time it was freed and re-floated in 15 minutes"

node.text:
A cargo ship briefly ran aground in the Suez Canal on Thursday. The ship was refloated within 15 minutes and did not impact traffic, officials said.

The incident comes several months after the Ever Given blocked the canal for six days. Click the link in our bio to read the full story.

(Credit: Kristin Carringer/Maxar)
#suezcanal

node.accessibility_caption: A graphic shows an image of a notebook. It reads: I hit burnout at work and felt useless. My therapist suggested this simple trick for improving my mood — here's how it works.

node.text:
Freelance journalist Anna Codrea-Rado was burned out after writing a book. A therapist prescribed a technique of scheduling leisure time alongside work, including SMART goals.

She describes how two months of "behavioral activation" has slowly helped lift her mood. Click the link in our bio and subscribe to Insider to read more about the technique.

Story by @annacod.

(Credit: Amina Kilpatrick/Insider, Getty Images)

node.accessibility_caption: A graphic shows an image of a notebook. It reads: I hit burnout at work and felt useless. My therapist suggested this simple trick for improving my mood — here's how it works.

A graphic shows a hand writing in a notebook with a blue outline. It reads Behavioral activation. I called it burnout, but the therapist identified it as low mood compounded by the fact I wasn't making time for a life outside of work. 

The remedy prescribed was called "behavioral activation." It's simply planning out your day to include more of the things you enjoy.

A graphic reads: How to organize task: You start by categorizing your tasks into three buckets: (1) important and necessary, things that will have a consequence if you don't do them, like work deadlines and paying bills, (2) routine, self-care activities that make your life better like working out and doing laundry, and (3) pleasurable, the stuff you enjoy like hobbies and socializing.
A graphic shows a hand writing in a notebook with a blue outline. It reads: Set SMART goals. specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, time-bound.

A graphic shows a hand writing in a notebook with a blue outline. It reads: A graphic Then you rank them in order of difficulty, and you take the easiest tasks first and create a schedule. Psychotherapist Athena Robinson said: “It's important to use hierarchical scheduling because the very beast that is depression often saps someone of the energy, motivation to start to do things on their own.”
A graphic reads: Subscribe to Inside read the rest more about behavioral activation.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Master your Money INSIDER Choosing the right place to keep your money is just as important as investing and saving it. Swipe to find the right account for you'.

node.text:
Choosing the right place to put money for a specific goal is just about as important as keeping up the habit of saving or investing. If you want to work smarter and not necessarily harder, you need to pay attention to where you're keeping your money. 

Savings and investments are often used interchangeably, especially when talking about retirement, but there's a crucial distinction when we're talking about financial accounts: Savings accounts are risk-free, and investment accounts have a sliding scale of inherent risk. 

Click the link in our bio to see which account is best for your financial goals.
 
Story by Tanza Loudenback.

(Credit @bi_graphics) #MasterYourMoneyBootcamp

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Master your Money INSIDER Choosing the right place to keep your money is just as important as investing and saving it. Swipe to find the right account for you'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Master your Money INSIDER Savings accounts High-yield yield savings accounts, CDs, and money-market accounts are the best options for keeping your money safe and liquid. If you tend to have a low risk tolerance, use these accounts for money you will use to fund a goal within the the next five years.'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Master your Money INSIDER Retirement Accounts These accounts are best to use when saving fo a long-term goal. Retirement accounts reward people with tax benefits in exchange for leaving their money to grow for many years. While retirement funds can be used for purposes other than retirement (like a down payment or educational expenses), it should be a last resort.'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Master your Money INSIDER Taxable Brokerage Accounts A brokerage account might appeal to you if you're flexible with your timeline and willing to stomach some risk. Unlike a retirement account, you can withdraw your balance at any time without a penalty, but you'll owe capital gains taxes on any profits.'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of phone and text that says 'Premium INSIDER I fell for a crypto scam on a dating app and lost $507. Then I learned I'm not the only one. Here's what happened.'.

node.text:
Simon (not his real name), a 30-year-old from Portsmouth, England, fell victim to a crypto scam via a dating app. In a conversation with Insider, he explained how it happened. 

Insider has verified his identity and agreed to use a pseudonym to protect his privacy. His words have been edited for length and clarity.

Read Simon’s essay at the link in our bio.

(Credit: Getty Images)

Simon not his real name), a 30-year-old from Portsmouth, England, fell victim to one of these crypto scams via dating app Tinder, where his match talked him into putting hundreds into what she said was a new coin. He spoke with Insider but asked for anonymity to protect his privacy. INSIDER'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER "She started talking about a cryptocurrency called PBM that the Chinese government was releasing, which she said was a unique opportunity because not everyone knew about it." Simon In a conversation with Insider'.

May be an image of text that says 'INSIDER "I started with $70 in USDT, a stablecoin linked to the US dollar, which I moved over to the site she had sent me. But she pressed me to add more, sol bought another $437 in USDT and moved it to the site." Simon In a conversation with Insider'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'He then realized he'd been scammed Around the time, he stayed with a friend.' "When told him about Lijia, he told me he thought was being scammed," he said. He showed him a Reddit thread where other people had reported matching on Tinder with cryptocurrency scammers who apeared to be in Hong Kong and China. Although China is working on a digital currency, it's expected to be a central-bank digital currency, not a cryptocurrency. There is no cryptocurrency called PBM. INSIDER'.

What's going on?" I tried to withdraw the money I'd invested. But, of course, the money never came through." Simon In a conversation with Insider'.

They added that the company had spent $100 million in 2021 on efforts to protect user safety. "This strong and important investment allows us to launch leading partnerships and new breakthrough technologies or products to keep protecting our members across the world," they said. INSIDER'.

node.text:
Brandy Melville employees say the brand is built on exploitation and discrimination. One staffer called it a "disgusting company" that "needs to be shut down."

According to Brandy Melville employees, CEO Stephan Marsan wants his staffers to be young, thin, pretty, and white. Every day, girls who work at the fast-fashion stores are required to send a full-body photo to executives. 

Insider spoke to more than 30 current and former employees from eight cities who suggest a business largely built on the exploitation of young women and discrimination against anyone who fails to meet the CEO's white, blond, and skinny ideal.

Click the link in our bio to read the full story by Kate Taylor.

(Credit: Brandy Melville USA/Instagram, Luca Rotondo, Franco Sorgi)
#brandymelville

Every day, girls who work at the fast-fashion stores are required to send a full-body photo to executives. Some are as young as 14. If Marsan thinks a girl is too heavy or unattractive, he demands that she be fired, according to Luca Rotondo, a former senior vice president.'.

During Rotondo's nearly nine years at the company Marsan instructed him to fire hundreds of employees, Rotondo said. "If she was Black, if she was fat he didn't want them in the store Rotondo told Insider.'.

Marsan texted Rotondo, writing in his native Italian that the store was "only hiring pieces of shit." They're going to destroy the store, Marsan wrote in a text message viewed by Insider. "Cacciala," Marsan demanded- or "kick her out."'.

In a filing in Rotondo's lawsuit, Bastiat USA, the company that operates Brandy Melville ocations in the United States, denied thatit "has ever fired an employee on account of his or her race." node.text:
Mel Burke is a culture writer and current MA student at Johns Hopkins University. She recently took on writing full time and decided to try only working on her novel late at night. 

For one work week, she wrote after her day was done, starting between 7:00 and 8:00 p.m. Although she was quite productive, she doesn't think it's worth missing social activities.

(Credit: Mel Burke)

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'INSIDER I traded a 9-to-5 routine to work like a night owl for a week. Here's what happened.'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Monday kicked off with a bang Night one started rocky, sitting down at 8:00 p.m. with a cup of tea to try and fuel some focus after a full day of freelance assignments. wrote for about two and a half hours, hitting 2,300 words. Given how mushy my brain felt, imagined drifting off to sleep immediately. But my brain was twitchy and confused by the late work until about 1:00 a.m. INSIDER'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'On Tuesday, I exceeded my goal again I sat down at 7:00 p.m. after another day of freelance work. got two writing sprints in before taking a dog-walking break. A little past 8:00 p.m., started to find my groove. stopped around 10:30 p.m., which gave me three-and-a-half hours total for the night, 2,091 words sprinted, and four chapter edited or revised. Again, for the day. was over my goal INSIDER'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'On Wednesday I faced the challenge of writing while tipsy had drinks planned after work, so by the time sat down to write it was past 10:00 p.m., which made this my latest writing sprint not only for the week but in a long time. And although tried to push through for another 1,000 words before bed, didn't make it, just barely landing my goal of 2,000 words for the night. INSIDER'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'By Thursday, of steam ran out had social plans again, this time for a movie night with friends after work. imagine writing regularly at night cuts into your social life. That, or more writers were drunk on the job than I'm fully aware of. Despite the ceaseless insistence that writers "write every day," sometimes you just have to take a day off. My word count for the day was zero and it still took me until 2:00 a.m. to fall asleep. INSIDER'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'But on Friday finished strong A reader I'd asked for feedback let me know when they' d be available, so under me to finish up the plot hole that had been killing my momentum. had a fresh fire sat down around 7:30 p.m. with the promise of a mostly empty weekend stretching ahead of me. Three hours later, I'd reached the two-thirds mark for editing my book, and I called it a night. INSIDER'.

Photo by Business Insider on September 07, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Overall, I didn't hate night-writing as much It was freeing to have flexibility in my schedule and approach my creative work without the nagging worry that hadn't finished paid work first. was surprised, too, was able to get done despite having already worked a full day. at how much I'll be going back to my daytime routines knowing that, if need it, the late hours are always there. INSIDER'.
